head.title: The Battle of CUNY: The Roots of Discontent

hedline.hl1: The Battle of CUNY: The Roots of Discontent

abstract.p: Letter from Prof Sandi E Cooper (College of Staten Island) comments on May 28 article, saying CUNY trustees lack the competence to shape curriculum

block.p: Re ''A Time for Dialogue at CUNY'' (editorial, May 28):

What makes the proposals for ''raising standards'' through a core curriculum unlikely to produce cooperative peace between faculty and administration is that they are based on false allegations. CUNY colleges largely already have general education requirements that introduce students to the intellectual goodies of most disciplines -- the result of faculty labors over decades.
Re ''A Time for Dialogue at CUNY'' (editorial, May 28):

What makes the proposals for ''raising standards'' through a core curriculum unlikely to produce cooperative peace between faculty and administration is that they are based on false allegations. CUNY colleges largely already have general education requirements that introduce students to the intellectual goodies of most disciplines -- the result of faculty labors over decades.

Trustees simply lack the competence to shape curriculums. They are supposed to be concerned with fund-raising and broad policy directions; history will provide a verdict about how successful CUNY trustees have been in those arenas.
The faculty cannot buy into peace at any price.
SANDI E. COOPER Staten Island, May 28, 2000
The writer, a professor of history at the College of Staten Island, CUNY, is a member of the University Faculty Senate executive committee.
